Karl Matthias Wantzen

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/4400447194781867
  • Última atualização do currículo em 24/11/2015

Professor Wantzen is working on ecological baselines for sustainable management of the environment and conservation of biodiversity. His expertise covers ecosystem research from the biochemical (molecular) to the ecosystem and biome levels, specifically for freshwater systems and their aquatic-terrestrial interaction zones. After studies on the Rhine River where he introduced novel freeze-core technologies to analyze the the ecotone between surface water and groundwater, he developed a GIZ-project on the environmental impacts of agriculture on Neotropical stream ecosystems for his PhD work at the Max-Planck-Institute of Limnology, which was rated ?summa cum laude?. Then he coordinated a research project funded by the German Ministry of Research BMBF for eight years at the Federal University of Mato Grosso Brazil, resulting in the build-up of a PhD program and a new national research insitute. This project focused on delivering scientific basics for floodplain and wetland management, as documented by a 31-chapter book, which he co-edited. His own work was on stable isotope analysis of food webs and on organic carbon in freshwater systems, for which he developed a world-wide comparison experiment. Back to Germany in 2001, he built up a DFG-funded research group on aquatic-terrestrial interactions at University of Konstanz, with a special focus on invasive species. His habilitation thesis on ecology, biodiversity and management of river-floodplain corridors was accepted in 2007. He is co-founder of the current 7 M? BMBF-Project ?Carbiocial? on carbon-wise management of Southern Amazonia. In 2010 he accepted a call as a full professor in Applied Aquatic Ecology at the University of Tours, where he built up new laboratories and the Chinon Center for Freshwater Studies, which he is currently leading, and from where he co-ordinates a 4M? project by the European Union to save the last populations of the Giant Freshwater Pearl Mussel in Europe by river management and artificial breeding. In 2014 he was nominated ?UNESCO Chair for River Culture/Fleuves et Patrimoine?, awarding his tireless efforts for knowledge transfer between Europe and the Tropics. January 2015, the Président de la Région Centre is acknowledging his engagement in France. (Texto informado pelo autor)
